2.68.text:
Marie:                     Hey
it's Marie Forleo and you are watching MarieTV,

8.16.text:
the place to be to create a business and life
you love. I got a question for you: have you

13.74.text:
ever struggled to create change in your life?
Maybe around a birthday, you've said, "this

20.87.text:
year is going to be different, it really is,"
but then it becomes a sad repeat of the past.

27.20.text:
If you've ever struggled to create meaningful
change in your life, my guest today is here

33.32.text:
Todd Herman is the founder of the Peak Athlete,
a peak performance coaching and researching

38.08.text:
company working with hundreds of pro and Olympic
athletes on the inner psychology of winning.

43.78.text:
Todd also consults with leading executives
and business owners on leadership, sales and

48.53.text:
communication. His corporate leadership programs
are used by over 17 organizations globally

54.65.text:
and three governments reaching over 250,000
people.

58.21.text:
In 2010, he was awarded the World's Greatest
Salesperson and the Con International Advertising

64.95.text:
Festival and has been featured on the Today
Show, the Australian Today Show, Sky Business,

69.40.text: the New York Times and other media.

72.07.text: Todd Herman, thank you for being on MarieTV.

76.00.text:
Todd:           I'm so happy to be
here.

77.92.text:
Marie:                     I
think you're amazing and you and I have been

80.25.text:
friends for years. One of the coolest things
that you taught me, and this was a few years

85.24.text:
back, was on the biology of change. It's
this concept and these ideas that really have

91.31.text:
stuck with me, so I am so excited to have
you share that with everybody here today.

97.48.text:
Lets get right into it. What's happening on
a cellular level when we try and create some

103.51.text:
kind of change? A new habit, learn a new skill,
anything like that.

108.07.text:
Todd:           There's a chemical
cocktail of changes happening inside of us

111.73.text:
and it's working from the inside out. Anytime
we're trying to break an old habit, embark

119.49.text:
on a new skill or try to improve ourselves,
generally there is a biological process that's

126.33.text:
going on inside of us and most people would
tap into it as an emotional part of what's

132.02.text:
going on. It's this part that trips people
up; it's this misunderstanding of what's

137.08.text:
happening that prevents people from actually
continuing on with the change. There's some

142.52.text:
great research that was done and last year,
the Nobel Prize in Chemistry was awarded to

149.42.text: two researchers on this very subject.

152.42.text:
What's interesting to note about the cells,
what's important to know, is that they are

156.79.text:
constantly receiving information and they're
constantly replicating themselves. It's

161.75.text:
important to know this because this is actually
what's happening when we're going through

164.72.text:
our process of change. When we actually start
on a process of embarking on a new skill or

170.14.text:
changing a bad habit or something like that,
we're actually sending some positive "juju"

175.14.text:
through our body. Positive emotion that comes
in the form of hormones; dopamine and serotonin

180.26.text:
would be the two main ones. But if our cells
are used to being constantly bombarded with

184.62.text:
cortisol, because they're receivers of information,
they're used to getting cortisol, just like

189.55.text:
hungry little hippos; they just wanting to
be fed anything and if you're constantly feeding

193.46.text:
them cortisol, they'll accept it. They're
going to get more of it and they're going

196.27.text:
to send information up saying, "give me
some more cortisol and stress." If you're

200.00.text:
wondering why you're always stressed out,
it's not that you're a bad person and

202.79.text:
you're supposed to be living that way; it's
just what your cells are used to.

206.10.text:
When we stick with change, the replication
of the cells that happens, if we're constantly

212.43.text:
giving them dopamine and endorphins, they're
going to want more dopamine and endorphins

217.38.text:
when they replicated because the cells replicate
based on the last information that happens

221.71.text:
Marie:                     Tracking
here, so we start to create a new habit; for

225.85.text:
example, we're starting to exercise. Before
our butts were on the couches, we're all

231.09.text:
stressed out all the time and all of a sudden
we said "alright, I'm going to start working

233.75.text:
out." You start sending these new hormones,
the dopamine and serotonin and your cells

238.76.text:
start getting bombarded with some new hormones
and they're shaking and they're replicating

244.69.text: then they want to start going in a new direction.

247.01.text:
Todd:           They're vibrating
away because they're not used to getting this

250.17.text:
information so they need to vibrate to accept
it because they need to change the receptor

253.69.text:
sites to allow in this new information. It's
this vibration that trips people up. This

258.70.text:
is the cause of what we would call self-sabotage
and resistance many times in people because

264.46.text:
they interpret this as "this doesn't really
feel good or doesn't feel right to me,"

270.02.text:
and that's their own story that they're
attaching to the cellular change that's

274.37.text:
happening. You got to remember that those
cells automatically always want the good stuff

278.49.text:
right away because they're still elements
of the need for cortisol. You are going to

282.70.text:
still get some stress going on in your body,
but overtime if we just stick with it, that's

286.49.text:
why the greatest breakthroughs always happen
when you are wanting to quit almost, and then

290.93.text:
around the next corner is this massive change
that happens for us.

295.13.text:
It's this knowing part, when I've shared
this with clients and even when we talked

299.65.text:
about it for the first time, that people relax
into it because now it explains so much of

305.03.text:
why sometimes we've quit and when we've
been doing something that was really positive

308.93.text:
but just knowing that this is how we work,
people can relax into the change more. It's

314.53.text:
like now you know what to expect. I'm not
going to be positive forever because day one

319.08.text:
exercise is easy, day two is easy too, day
three a little bit of resistance kicking in

323.51.text:
because maybe we're a little bit achy, day
four maybe we don't want to go to the gym

328.43.text:
and day five we just end up quitting on ourselves.
The change was happening if we would have

334.10.text:
just stuck with it, then when our cells are
used to all this dopamine and serotonin that's

338.95.text:
coming at it, they're going to be wanting
more of that which means that the activities

342.60.text:
that you're going to be choosing are going
to lead you to be sending that information

346.52.text:
back down; the activities, the action you
take on a daily basis.

349.05.text:
Marie:                     It's
almost like we have to stick through it to

350.85.text:
get through that transition period so that
our cells have built those new receptors,

356.09.text:
want the dopamine, want the good stuff and
then they become hungry hippos for the good

360.17.text: stuff; it's like give me that juice.

363.45.text:
Todd:           And you're only going
to be doing the things that give them the

365.22.text:
juice, which is usually these new activities
and new habits that you've done in your

369.59.text:
Marie:                     What
we're doing is misinterpreting some really

373.35.text:
good stuff that's happening inside of our
body especially when we're around that stage

378.47.text:
with resistance. I think resistance is such
an interesting topic so let's dive a little

384.22.text:
Todd:           After all the work
that I've done with professional athletes,

387.44.text:
amateur athletes, Olympic athletes and executives
as well, there's basically two categories

392.34.text:
of people that I've classed people in; there's
OWW brainers and WOW brainers. The difference

401.67.text:
between the two is this: OOW brain people,
when they're faced with a challenge, some

407.33.text:
sort of obstacle, when they're going through
a process of change will automatically start

413.73.text:
the dialogue or the story that they tell themselves.
They feel this vibration that's going on

417.41.text:
and then what they attach to it is "I'm
not really feeling this, this isn't right

423.01.text:
for me, why should I bother anyway, I've always
been like this," things like that is all

430.09.text:
wrapped around that type of story. When you're
telling yourself that, of course you're going

434.69.text: to end up quitting on it.

436.66.text:
There's basically three categories of story
that we wrap around it; there is this feeling

443.29.text:
of being stuck, this feeling of being bored
and then this need to feel safe, retracting

454.03.text:
into ourselves so it's like a comfort zone.
People are stuck, they're bored and they're

459.63.text:
safe. If you notice that's what happening
in your life, you've fallen into this path

465.57.text:
Marie:                     The
OWW brain too is like "ow, that hurts, I

468.92.text:
want to step away, this isn't feeling right,
this isn't feeling good, let me go retreat

472.68.text:
to my old habits." If we can, before we
go onto the WOW brain, I've seen this so much

477.05.text:
in the programs that I teach because I see
the two different people and the folks that

481.50.text:
have the OWW brain the moment that they're
trying a new framework in marketing or they're

488.32.text:
trying to be more organized or trying to stick
to a schedule, they're like "I'm just not

492.69.text:
built like this, this doesn't work for me,"
and that's amazing because I'll see this

497.34.text:
whole other track of people that respond to
the same information in a different way and

503.33.text:
Todd:           It's not like we're
just one thing; it's segmented parts of

510.09.text:
our life. For me, it could be the idea of
me giving up chocolate cake; that's OWW

516.28.text:
to me. Another word that's wrapped around
it is pain; it's a pain part of our brain

522.98.text:
and OWW is about pain. The dialogue that happens
and continues on with that is "maybe my

531.17.text:
friends will leave me as well if I continue
on this." Here's the reality: if you're

534.30.text:
going to build a business for yourself and
you're going to become more successful, you're

537.48.text:
going to lose friends. You will. I did; you
probably did as well. You don't hang around

544.28.text:
Marie:                     Lets
talk about the WOW brain.

547.17.text:
Todd:           WOW brain people,
when they're going through this resistance,

551.94.text:
is they're seeing things as more pleasurable
and it's "this is feeling really good,

559.30.text:
I can't wait to see what happens out of this,
I wonder what opportunities are going to unfold

563.22.text:
for me because of this, there's so many things
that I'm learning and growing and I never

567.98.text:
would have expected this." It's all about
this sense of WOW. Three other categories

577.04.text:
that they revolve around is growth, confidence
is another and the other one is adventure.

587.39.text:
People that are going through the OWW brain,
they're dealing with feeling stuck, bored

592.31.text:
and feeling the need for safety; growth, confidence
and adventure for people that are in the WOW

600.51.text:
When you move those circles together, if growth,
confidence and adventure were all circles

604.29.text:
and we moved them together, where growth and
confidence overlap, then we get momentum when

609.51.text:
we're growing and we feel good about our
growth and we're moving on things. Momentum

614.36.text:
is the exact opposite of feeling stuck. Then
when we have confidence and adventure coming

620.21.text:
together, now we have excitement in our life
as well. Excitement is the exact opposite

624.54.text:
of feeling bored. Then we have growth and
adventure, which is all about transformation.

630.46.text:
When we go on an adventure and we grow from
it, we transform and we're not safe. And

635.62.text: in the center of it all is leadership.

637.01.text:
When you take a look at your own brand, and
I'm not doing this because I'm on MarieTV

640.18.text:
and give you a bunch of affirmations, it has
all those things going on and if people just

645.76.text:
wrapped their lives more around this idea
of just growing, getting more confidence from

650.72.text:
our growth and learning to look at life with
more of an adventurous spirit, then change

657.34.text:
isn't so daunting. Plus with this new knowledge
of this chemical cocktail that's going to

661.80.text:
go is going to go on all the time anyway and
I'm tired of feeding those hungry hippos nothing

667.50.text:
Marie:                     Right.
I love this. This is so fun. Every time I

670.37.text:
hear you talk about this, I really just get
excited. We've got the framework, we're

675.38.text:
starting to know this, we've got the OWW brain
and the WOW brain and we all have a little

679.10.text:
bit of both in our lives, so let's go on.
If we find ourselves in the position of being

685.13.text:
in OWW associating some kind of pain pulling
back when we know the change that we want

690.43.text:
to make is really in our best interest, it's
something that's really good for us and

693.94.text:
something ultimately we want. What are some
practical steps that we can take to support

699.38.text: ourselves to move into more of that WOW position?

702.80.text:
Todd:           There are five prescriptions
that I give people. One is you have to have

709.63.text:
a vision that's clear and very specific.
People have heard that before. It's not

713.76.text:
that its something new and shiny object type
of thing. I'm not talking about this grand

719.27.text:
vision off into the future but if it's a
very small change that we're trying to make

722.61.text:
or if we're trying to break a habit, what
does that look like, specifically what am

726.21.text:
I trying to change about myself or what's
the new skill? If we take a look at growth

731.41.text:
and confidence and adventure, what's a vision
that I have about my growth that I can be

738.67.text:
growing in my business and what does that
look like for me and very tangible it has

743.11.text:
Marie:                     I
can give you an example that can help illustrate

745.69.text:
this. I just did this 14 day detox with Josh
and it wasn't necessarily like I had this

753.34.text:
ultra clear vision of what it would look like,
but it was a specific thing. These 14 days,

759.46.text:
it was concrete, I understood there was a
plan, there was a place I was going to get

763.10.text:
to and I knew the kind of things I was going
to eliminate on my path, so it made it so

767.15.text:
easy rather than this big grand vision of
being the perfect healthy person forever.

772.94.text:
It was specific, it was concrete and it gave
us something to work from.

775.87.text:
Todd:           You used the keyword
"path"; the path is everything. You saw

778.52.text:
the path. There was no guessing and uncertainty.
Uncertainty is the enemy to the OWW brainer.

784.56.text:
If there is uncertainty, you're going to get
resistance and self-sabotage in your life

787.82.text:
then. Just be specific and clear about what
it is that you're trying to go after.

792.59.text:
The second thing is to set trigger goals for
yourself. Trigger goals are about the little

800.91.text:
micro changes that we need to be set up for
ourselves in order to maybe accomplish the

806.10.text:
bigger goal. If I'm trying to start a new
exercise regimen, a trigger goal is if I pull

814.21.text:
the thread on that goal of going to the gym,
what's one of the first actions I would even

818.23.text:
ever have to take in order to get to the gym?
It would be four times this week, I'm going

823.24.text:
to get dressed up in my Lululemon gear in
my home because probability says that I'm

836.67.text:
more than like going to take the next step
which is maybe walk out the door. Trigger

841.64.text:
goals would be five times this week, I'm going
to get dressed up and it's the complete

844.46.text:
opposite about what most people hear about
goal setting. I want to find what is the behavioral

848.84.text:
action step that you can take because I know
that if I get you to walking down that path,

854.84.text:
the likelihood of you getting to the gym is
just that much more likely.

857.90.text:
The next goal on top of that would be to open
up the door five times this week with the

861.95.text:
mission of going to the gym. We're not even
at the gym yet and those are things we do

868.07.text:
when we accomplish it. There is a little dopamine
dump that we get because we did achieve the

873.24.text:
thing that we set up that we were going to
do.

875.17.text:
Marie:                     It's
almost building on small wins. I can think

877.20.text:
about it in terms of productivity. I know
for me one of the biggest habits that I developed

882.47.text:
that serves me so much, and I always recommend
it, end of day and take out my notebook, setup

887.98.text:
for the next day. Huge, simple trigger goal
impacts my level of accomplishment, how I

895.07.text:
feel about myself, how rested I can be when
I go to bed, just doing that one simple tiny

901.69.text:
action that cascades into incredible results
in every part of my life.

906.45.text:
Todd:           What's funny about
that goal you set for yourself is when I take

909.71.text:
a look at one of the hallmarks of a WOW brainer,
people who do achieve quite a bit, that's

916.24.text:
one of their things that they. They are fantastic
at planning out their tomorrow, today.

920.70.text:
Marie:                     I
love it; it gets me high. I get so excited.

924.63.text:
Todd:           Think about it. For
me, it's like this sense of excitement expectancy

927.88.text:
now because I'm taking control of my day,
not control in that I'm going to force things

932.54.text:
to happen but there's an internal power that
we get from that.

935.44.text:
Marie:                     Absolutely.
Also, a sense that we know that we can't control

938.98.text:
so much of what happens so to go in at least
with a plan of "okay, this is what's really

943.66.text:
important for me, so no matter what else happens,
I got this to go in there with. It may not

948.12.text: always work out but at least coming in prepared."

952.58.text:
Todd:           Number three would
be to set improvement goals. Improvement goals

960.92.text:
are really important and are all about numbers
with a date attached to them. The great thing

967.83.text:
about photo albums is that we can see change
in photo albums. When I see myself at 5 or

972.97.text:
at 15, I can see the visual change that's
happening, but when people maybe sign up for

978.92.text:
one of your programs, if I don't set up
an improvement goal for myself, then it's

982.95.text:
really hard for me to know and get feedback
for myself of, is this improving, am I growing

990.41.text:
from this, so I can get more confidence with
my abilities and capabilities.

994.99.text:
An improvement goal would be, for example,
if it's working out again; I will improvement

998.35.text:
the number of pushups I can do consecutively
from 5 to 15 by X date, six weeks from now,

1004.62.text:
four weeks from now, whatever it is. If someone
is in a sales type role, I will improve the

1009.58.text:
number of successful calls that I make to
prospects from three per day to six per day,

1015.48.text:
by a date. Then I can put that on a plot chart
and I can see it go up or I can see it go

1021.70.text:
down, and in the feedback loop we see, "no
wonder my sales are dropping because I'm not

1027.05.text:
doing that one little activity." I don't
need to beat myself up over it; it's just

1032.15.text:
Marie:                     It's
that classic phrase; anything measured improves,

1036.71.text:
anything measured and reported improves exponentially.
Again I'll go back to this detox I was doing.

1044.11.text:
It's related but I drew 10 little glasses
on my one sheet of paper every day because

1049.65.text:
that was that I needed to do, have 10 full
glasses of water everyday and I got such a

1053.61.text:
high out of ticking those little babies off,
it just feels good, but now I have a record

1058.75.text: as you say of exactly what I did.

1061.40.text:
Todd:           And there's this
whole movement in the online space too of

1066.71.text:
Marie:                     Is
that related to quantified self?

1069.53.text:
Todd:           Growth hacking is
all about finding little micro changes in

1074.73.text:
the conversion on your page that maybe it's
1% improvement; the 1% on that page plus 1%

1081.35.text:
on the next page plus the 1% on the next page
increases to 10% actually overall. I'm trying

1087.30.text:
to growth hack performance for professional
athletes or growth hack performance for executives

1092.39.text:
or an entire team of people. The great thing
about it is it doesn't scare the limbic

1098.57.text:
part of our brain that's all about fight,
flight, freeze and things like that; we're

1103.38.text:
looking for micro changes, so we set improvement
goals for ourselves.

1107.17.text:
The fourth one is to gather a tribe around
yourself. A tribe can look many different

1116.43.text:
ways. It could be a coach or a mentor. It
could be a friend who's already gone through

1120.83.text:
what you're hoping to go through and be a
coach for you. It can be an online community.

1126.65.text:
That's the great thing about the Internet
now; there are all these micro niches that

1129.55.text:
are everywhere that have interests that I'm
shocked at sometimes but they're there to

1134.61.text:
help out. There are tons of helpful people
out there that are there to gather around

1138.68.text:
you and cheer you on. Then if you start reporting
to people your improvement goals and your

1146.18.text:
trigger goals and things like that, people
go "you think differently than me." Now

1151.74.text:
you can actually get to that place where we
all want to get to; it's a natural part

1155.79.text:
of the human experience, which is to share
with other people. That's what the hero's

1161.49.text:
journey is all about.  We go on this journey
and Luke Skywalker comes back with the magical

1166.46.text:
elixir and he can help save other people.
When we go through and we actually complete

1171.31.text:
the change that we're trying to go on, now
we have data, we've got experience and then

1175.47.text:
we become so much more valuable to the people
around us.

1177.67.text:
Marie:                     Love
it. Now we're going to talk about my favorite

1181.50.text:
one, which is script your setbacks. I love
this; tell us what that means.

1186.24.text:
Todd:           Anytime we're going
through change, there's always going to be

1189.38.text:
moments that are going to challenge the change
that we're trying to go through and whether

1194.02.text:
it's breaking back habits or whether it's
trying to start a new skill.  Scripting your

1197.55.text:
setbacks, I also call it the positive power
of negative preparation, is all about what

1204.47.text:
am I going to do in the moment when someone
says "do you want some chocolate cake."

1210.37.text:
If I'm on this health kick that I'm trying
to drop this 7 LBs around my waist, just thinking

1217.97.text:
about that ahead of time it's going to be
a 
definitive "no, thanks." It just greases

1231.65.text:
the slide for us in our own heads. We don't
need to think about it; it's just there

1237.87.text:
Scripting your setbacks, we can do it in so
many parts of our life. When I'm working with

1243.52.text:
a professional athlete, there's a lot of times
where there's tons of trash talk that's

1247.51.text:
going on the field of play and sometimes people
can be going through very sensitive times

1251.89.text:
in their life. We need to think that stuff
through so that they don't cost their team

1257.14.text:
a penalty which then costs them the game or
something like that. The same thing happens

1262.26.text:
in business. What are you going to do when
the deal that you thought was the sure thing

1266.29.text:
that was going to be closing doesn't happen?
What are you going to do?

1269.25.text:
Marie:                     What
are you going to do when you want to put that

1272.68.text:
video out or that blog post or the book proposal
and you get rejected or criticized or whatever?

1279.46.text:
Todd:           Because it will happen.
What am I going to feel? It's not just the

1286.15.text:
doing part but what am I going to feel as
well. What am I going to see? Who am I going

1288.92.text:
to call? Do I have a support system around
me? Don't think about it; just do it. That's

1295.74.text:
what the power of doing the trigger goals
is as well, have my Lululemon pants laying

1300.39.text:
out for me so I don't have to think about
it too much; just have them staring me in

1304.18.text:
the face. Scripting your setbacks is exceptionally
powerful. Everyone talks about positive thinking

1310.15.text:
but really there's a lot most power in actually
thinking through the challenges because if

1315.24.text:
we think that life is one big Pollyanna episode,
it's just not. We would talk about it in

1324.48.text:
the context of it's just mental weakness
because I talk about mental toughness so much.

1327.67.text:
Mental toughness is knowing what to do when
things aren't going well.

1331.75.text:
Marie:                     Scripting
your setbacks just opens up so many file folders.

1338.84.text:
Even when especially because I know eating
and being healthy and taking care of your

1341.90.text:
body is something I feel like all of us strive
for and there's always a different level in

1346.20.text:
something we're experimenting with. Back
to this detox just because it was recent,

1351.34.text:
I was travelling and going to speak at a seminar
right in the midst of one of the most intense

1357.25.text:
parts of it, and it was 14 days long. In the
idea of scripting setbacks, I planned out

1363.27.text:
all my meals, I know I was going to be on
a plane, I planned everything out so that

1369.17.text:
I wouldn't be stuck in a hotel room going
"what am I going to eat, I want to kill

1372.73.text: myself," and then a cheeseburger comes.

1375.63.text:
Todd:           It's in those moments
of weakness when we usually make the decision

1380.84.text:
that takes away from the goals that we're
trying to go after. This gets to the other

1384.68.text:
point of we're expending will power throughout
our entire day. If we're waiting until the

1388.93.text:
end of the day and expecting ourselves to
follow through in a whole bunch of change,

1394.36.text:
it's treating ourselves very poorly because
we should be front loading our day with all

1400.75.text: the change that we're trying to do.

1402.47.text:
Marie:                     Todd,
this was fantastic. Thank you so much for

1406.69.text:
taking the time out today. I know you have
a new baby girl in your life and she is beautiful,

1412.10.text:
I love Molly and obviously I love your wife,
Val; she's amazing too. I really appreciate

1417.16.text:
you being here with all of us and sharing
this incredible knowledge. I feel like people

1421.04.text:
are going to just freak out. I love it. It
just helps me out since we had that conversation

1427.57.text:
Marie:                     Now
Todd and I have a challenge for you. Take

1430.40.text:
a look in your own life. When you're trying
to create change, do you have an OWW brain

1435.13.text:
or a WOW brain? Obviously we both have both,
but where do you tend to go most often? If

1441.13.text:
you've been having a hard time trying to
make any kind of change recently, which one

1445.06.text:
of the five steps do you feel will help you
the most? Tell us all about it in the comments

1451.00.text:
As always, the best conversations happen after
the episode over at MarieForleo.com so go

1456.15.text: there and leave a comment now.

1459.07.text:
Did you like this video? If so, subscribe
and share it with your friends. If you want

1464.70.text:
even more great resources to create a business
and life that you love, plus some personal

1469.76.text:
insights from me that I only talk about in
email, get those sweet buns over to MarieForleo.com

1474.93.text: and sign up for email updates.

1477.18.text:
Stay on your game and keep going for your
dreams because the world needs that special

1481.56.text:
gift that only you have. Thank you so much
for watching and I'll catch you next time
